vactypedoses¶

vizcovidfr.line_charts.line_charts.vactypedoses(vaccine_type='All vaccines', color_pal='darkblue', color_pal2='orangered', color_pal3='green', font_size=16, font_family='Franklin Gothic Medium', font_color='white', bgcolor='darkslategrey', template='plotly_dark')¶

Make an interactive line chart of France vaccine storage, according to the vaccine type.

Parameters

  • vaccine_type (str, optional, default='All vaccines') – the vaccine type we want to display. Either ‘Pfizer’, ‘Moderna’, ‘AstraZeneca’ or ‘All vaccines’. In this latter case, the three vaccine types are represented. It is possible to hover one’s mouse over the curves to get thorough information.

  • color_pal (str, optional, default='darkblue') –

    the color of the chosen vaccine type curve. If ‘All vaccines’ vaccine_type is chosen, set the color of the ‘Pfizer’ curve.

    For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • color_pal2 (str, optional, default='orangered') –

    Only if ‘All vaccines’ vaccine_type is chosen. Set the color of ‘Moderna’ curve.

    For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • color_pal3 (str, optional, default='green') –

    Only if ‘All vaccines’ vaccine_type is chosen. Set the color of ‘AstraZeneca’ curve.

    For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • font_size (int, optional, default=16) – the size of characters in hover labels

  • font_family (str, optional, default='Franklin Gothic Medium') –

    the font family of the characters in hover labels.

    For reference, see http://jonathansoma.com/site/lede/data-studio/matplotlib/list-all-fonts-available-in-matplotlib-plus-samples/

  • font_color (str, optional, default='white') – the color of characters in hover labels, For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • bgcolor (str, optional, default='darkslategrey') – the background color of all hover labels on graph. For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • template (str, optional, default='plotly_dark') –

    the visual style we want the graph to be based on.

    For reference, see https://plotly.com/python/templates/.

Returns

animated line chart representing the actual dose number of the chosen vaccine type (in storage).

Return type

plotly.graph_objects.Figure

Notes

Manipulation tips:

  • click on a vaccine type label on the top right of the graph to remove it from the chart.

  • click on the camera icon on the very top right of the chart to save the image as a png.

  • click on the ‘zoom in’ icon to zoom in, or on the icon ‘zoom out’ to zoom out, on the chart.

  • click on the ‘autoscale’ icon to let plotly autoscale the chart.

For colorbind safe colors

See https://colorbrewer2.org/#type=qualitative&scheme=Dark2&n=3. Default colors in that function are colorbind safe.

vacdoses¶

vizcovidfr.line_charts.line_charts.vacdoses(unit='doses', font_size=16, font_family='Franklin Gothic Medium', font_color='white', bgcolor='darkslategrey', template='plotly_dark')¶

Make an interactive line chart of France vaccine storage.

Parameters

  • unit (str, optional, default='doses') –

    the type of dose units we want to display. Either ‘doses’ or ‘cdu’ (shorts for ‘common dispensing units’),

    • ’doses’:

      display the evolution of total vaccine doses in storage, from January 2021 until now. (checkouts are not made everyday).

    • ’cdu’:

      display the evolution of total vaccine bottles in storage, from January 2021 until now. (checkouts are not made everyday).

    For ‘Pfizer’ vaccine, the cdu conversion rate per dose is multiplied by 6. For Moderna and AstraZeneca vaccines, the cdu conversion rate per dose is multiplied by 10.

  • font_size (int, optional, default=16) – the size of characters in hover labels.

  • font_family (str, optional, default='Franklin Gothic Medium') – the font family of the characters in hover labels. For reference, see http://jonathansoma.com/site/lede/data-studio/matplotlib/list-all-fonts-available-in-matplotlib-plus-samples/.

  • font_color (str, optional, default='white') – the color of characters in hover labels. For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • bgcolor (str, optional, default='darkslategrey') –

    the background color of all hover labels on graph.

    For reference, see http://www.python-simple.com/img/img45.png.

  • template (str, optional, default='plotly_dark') –

    the visual style we want the graph to be based on.

    For reference, see https://plotly.com/python/templates/.

Returns

An interactive line chart representing the actual amount in storage of vaccine doses, according to the chosen unit.

Return type

plotly.graph_objects.Figure

Notes

Manipulation tips:

  • click on the camera icon on the very top right of the chart to save the image as a png.

  • click on the ‘zoom in’ icon to zoom in, or on the icon ‘zoom out’ to zoom out, on the chart.

  • click on the ‘autoscale’ icon to let plotly autoscale the chart.

keytimeseries¶

vizcovidfr.line_charts.line_charts.keytimeseries(place='France', criterion='hospitalisation', evo=True, average=True)¶

Make a time series about information concerning the evolution of the COVID-19 in France or a sub-part of France.

Parameters

  • place (str, optional, default='France') – ‘France’ for the whole territory or the (french) name of a region, for reference, see https://www.regions-et-departements.fr/regions-francaises

  • criterion (str, optional, default='hospitalisation') –

    The figure of interest in French suc as “deces” , “cas”

    • ’cas_confirmes’:

      number of confirmed cases

    • ’deces’:

      cumulated number of deaths

    • ’reanimation’:

      number of people in intensive care

    • ’hospitalisation’:

      number of hospitalized people

    • ’gueris’:

      number of cured people

  • evo (bool, optional, default=True) – if True: new per day if False: cumulative

  • average – if True: evolution on a 7 day moving average

Returns

A time series until today since the beginning of the records of the figure of interest

Return type

plotly.graph_objects.Figure

Examples

>>> keytimeseries(place='Occitanie', criterion='gueris',
...               evo=False, average=True)

>>> keytimeseries(place='France', criterion='cas_confirmes',
...               evo=True, average=False)
